entry.title: Libre/Open blockchain / cryptographic ASICs
entry.summary:
In a detailed discussion on the impact of technological advancements on Bitcoin mining energy consumption, an interesting perspective was presented regarding the decisions miners face when new, more energy-efficient hardware becomes available. The dialogue illustrates a scenario where a miner has access to hardware that can produce 1 Exahash of mining power using 1 watt of energy, earning them 2 BTC. With the introduction of new technology allowing the same mining power (1 Exohash) for only 0.5 watt, a miner is faced with two choices. The first option involves purchasing a single unit of the new hardware, thus reducing energy consumption to 0.5 watts and increasing net earnings to 1.5 BTC after accounting for electricity costs. Alternatively, the miner could opt to buy two units of the new hardware, effectively doubling their mining output to 2 Exohash at the original 1 watt energy consumption, leading to a larger net gain of 3.0 BTC after electricity costs.
The analysis extends by considering the dynamics of Bitcoin's difficulty adjustment mechanism. If all miners collectively decide to increase their hash rate by investing in more efficient hardware without reducing overall energy consumption, the global mining hash rate would double. Consequently, Bitcoin's difficulty adjustment would increase to match this surge in mining power, potentially diminishing returns for those who chose not to expand their operations. This suggests that, in the absence of physical limitations such as space, rational miners will likely continue to invest in additional units of more efficient hardware rather than reduce their energy usage. Therefore, despite advancements in energy efficiency, the total energy consumption of Bitcoin mining is unlikely to decrease as miners strive to maximize earnings by leveraging more powerful technology.
The conversation also briefly touches upon the energy consumption of computers running BitTorrent software compared to those operating full Bitcoin nodes. It suggests that the energy used by a computer running Bitcoin software continuously is not significantly higher than that of one running BitTorrent, implying that the energy demands of Bitcoin mining are relatively moderate when compared to other digital activities. This comparison serves to contextualize the energy consumption of Bitcoin mining within the broader spectrum of everyday technology use.
